unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Average Number of Emails
question_text: A school teacher wonders, on average, how many emails does he get a day? To investigate, he selects 30 30 random days during the last year, and calculates the mean. His results shows that he got a mean of ¯ x = 52.5 x ¯ = 52.5 . Can the teacher safely assume that his true average number of emails was 52.5 52.5 ?

choices.text: Yes, since n = 30 n = 30 , the Central Limit Theorem says this result is valid.
Yes, since the days were random, we can generalize this result for the entire population.
Yes, since the 10 % 10 % condition is met, the teacher can use this statistic.
No, since the distribution is not stated as Normal, he can not use this statistic.
No, since the number found is a statistic, the true population mean most likely differs from this amount.

solution:
When dealing with statistics , numbers that describe a sample, and parameters , numbers that describe a population, it is important to remember that rarely do statistics equal the population parameter. In this case, ¯ x = 52.5 x ¯ = 52.5 is a statistic, a sample mean. If the teacher had chosen 30 30 different days, it is very unlikely that he would've gotten the same sample mean. This is due to Sampling Variability .

Therefore, since the sample mean was only based off one sample, the teacher should not believe this is the true population mean, and use an inference method to find plausible values for his true population mean.

Choice 'E' is correct.
